newsitem.title: ZAIRE: Zaire fights rebels on many fronts, opposes talks.
newsitem.headline: Zaire fights rebels on many fronts, opposes talks.

text.p: Zaire's counter-offensive against rebels has run into resistance with its mercenary-backed army fighting rebels on several fronts, government and military sources said on Thursday.

But the government, which has opted for a military solution to the three-month-old Tutsi-led revolt in the east, once again ruled out negotiations, saying troops from neighbouring countries must leave first.

"There is a dynamic developing in certain quarters for Zaire to negotiate with the rebels," Deputy Foreign Minister Henri Thomas Lokondo Yoka told reporters in Kinshasa. "The government will not negotiate with the aggressors until we have recovered all the territory that has been occupied," he said.
Zaire accuses Rwanda, Burundi and most recently Uganda of invading to back the rebels, who launched their offensive in October and hold towns and territory in the east.
All three deny their troops are fighting inside Zaire.
A senior Zairean defence ministry official said Ugandan troops backing the rebels had reached Bunia in Upper Zaire. Zaire's army earlier claimed to have retaken part of Bunia.
An army communique issued in Kinshasa on Thursday said Ugandan troops were fighting to take towns such as Watsa and Isiro, hundreds of km (miles) into Upper Zaire province.
Military sources told Reuters earlier Zairean soldiers and foreign mercenaries were based in Watsa.
The army accused Rwandan troops of fighting on the road from Walekale, just over 100 km (70 miles) from the Rwandan border, to Kisangani, headquarters for the Zairean counter-offensive.
It said Burundian soldiers were aiding rebels advancing down the road to the southern mining province of Shaba and were within 30 km (20 miles) of it.
The defence ministry official, who asked not to be identified, said they were within 70 km (45 miles) of Kalemie, home town of rebel leader Laurent Kabila.
"We are having to fight on several fronts," he said.
The accounts from Kinshasa were in line with reports from Rwanda that rebels in eastern Zaire were pushing south and west, opening new fronts to frustrate the army's counter-offensive.
"The strategy is clearly to stretch out the front as far as possible," a Western diplomat in neighbouring Rwanda said.
After losing a long strip of eastern territory to Kabila's rebels late last year, Zaire's ailing President Mobutu Sese Seko and his government launched a counter-attack.
Reports from the field suggest Zaire's army, which launched its offensive on January 20, is increasingly on the defensive.
Western sources in Kinshasa in radio contact with the region said Watsa had already fallen to rebels with Ugandan backing.

The sources said the rebels and their allies had large supplies of anti-aircraft missiles and rocket-propelled grenades. Zairean troops and allied mercenaries had fled the superior numbers and weaponry of the rebels.
Zaire has significantly increased its arsenal, importing combat helicopters, fighter jets, artillery and munitions as well as around 300 mercenaries.

But senior military officials complain in private that despite recently acquired military hardware, the army has still to be given the full logistical support and munitions it needs -- in part due to foreign restrictions on arms sales.
"Zaire finds itself in the situation of a boxer, well trained but with its hands tied by a military embargo, happy to take and dodge the blows delivered by the enemy," the army said.
